fields.headline: Salami style
fields.bodyText: In reading your article (18 September) on the arrest of the alleged terror suspects threatening the pope – who have since been released without charge – I was surprised to see this: "Quick [a former anti-terrorist officer] added there was a public misconception about the purpose of arrests in terrorism cases: 'An arrest is a means of investigation, it does not mean someone is guilty of an offence.'" Things are bad in America, but even we don't arrest people just so we can investigate them. The reaction to the terrorist threat is frequently worse than the threat itself on both sides of the Atlantic. Tom Kelly West Springfield, Massachusetts, USA • I read with interest that the Queen gave the pope a gift of a set of drawings by the 16th-century painter Hans Holbein the Younger (Report, 17 September). Is this the same Hans Holbein the Younger, the Lutheran and favourite court painter to Henry VIII – the first monarch to contest the legitimacy of the Vatican state? I think we should be told. Tony Fitzgerald Nottingham • Surely the Vatican must realise that "popemobile" is very much a 1980s term. How about something a little more 21st century: papal carrier, perhaps? Mick Pearson Machynlleth, Powys • Nicole Polonsky (Letters, 18 September) writes that Jana Sterbak beat Lady Gaga by 23 years by wearing a dress made of meat in 1987. I wore a two-piece suit made of salami to the Slade post-graduate private view in 1979 (and have the photos to prove it). Bob Connolly London • Re the letter from Tony Latham (14 September): our two drums on a Lufthansa flight in 2004 were upgraded to seats in business class. My husband and I were not. Jeannie Green Cambridge • I thought that everyone knew that the Bonanza theme always happened in your head at 9.50am – cowboy time (Letters, 18 September): 10 to to10 to to10 to to10 to10 10, 10 to to10 to to 10 to to 10 to to10 to to 10 to 10. Stuart Butler Rodborough, Gloucestershire
